1) So you are with your partner having some private thoughts and you accidentally dropped a "Sigh".
2) Your partner turns around and asks the automatic "What wrong?"
3) You immediately reply "Nothing!" to avoid the unpleasant and unnecessary conversation that will inadvertently come up later.
4) Unconvinced and relentless, your partner puts on pressure by saying "No seriously, what wrong?".
5) You can see where this is going, we have all been there.

As someone with Cystic fibrosis, I used to be on a Bipap machine while sleeping. It was super uncomfortable as it was very unnatural feeling assisted breathing. The deep breathes definitely are comforting as I can notice very small changes in how well I’m breathing.

i started having trouble breathing deeply about two months ago. Thought it was covid at first so went to the hospital to get tested. Test came out negative. Got a blood test and x ray just in case. Nothing was wrong. Doctor couldn't figure it out. Was then told that my oxygen level was also fine from just normal breathing. However, I feel the urge to take deep breaths, to the point some of my muscles would go numb or even get panic attacks. Consulted another doctor and was then told it's related to life stress and mentality, and breathing deeply wouldn't matter as long as I can breath normally. Now scishow says that deep breaths are crucial.... and it's scaring me out.. :(      any medical experts here that can share some insight please?

Ventilators are more commonplace than most people think. Society generally associates ventilators with patients who are critically ill. What if I told you that many surgery clinics had ventilators built into their anaesthesia machines. This is because even during routine general anaesthesia, the body is chemically paralyzed and too tired to breathe on its own. This means the anaesthetist needs to insert a large catheter into the windpipe to deliver oxygen and anaesthetic gases to the lungs and remove metabolic wastes like CO2 during surgery.
So... I'm interested to find out if there's any particular reason we don't breathe deeply enough to keep all our alveoli open all of the time?
